docs.lead_paragraph: Debra Winchell, 50, is single with no siblings, and her mother lives in an apartment complex for the elderly. The combination leaves her feeling especially vulnerable as her quest for work persists. ''I have no place to go if things fall through,'' she said.

headline.main: For Many, Uncertainty, Fear and Shame Often Follow Pink Slips: Safety Net Thins As Search Persists

docs.abstract: Profile of Debra Winchell, who is single, out of work and has no family to fall back on; Winchell describes anxiety she feels at prospect of finding another job; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lee Daves, 54, is coming to the end of his unemployment benefits and is not sure what he will do next. ''I'm going to find something soon,'' he said. ''I have to. It may not be what I want. If I have to wash dishes, that's what I'll do. Hopefully I can do better than that.''

headline.main: For Many, Uncertainty, Fear and Shame Often Follow Pink Slips: 'Slow the Bleeding' By Lowering Sights

docs.lead_paragraph: Sixty is the magic number for the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid. It is the number of votes he needs to overcome any Republican filibusters that might block the health care bill. It is also the number of senators in the Democratic caucus. But in many ways, 60 is also a mirage -- falsely raising Democrats' hopes, particularly those of more liberal senators, that they have the muscle to push the health care bill without making concessions to centrists in both parties.
docs.abstract: Sixty is magic number for Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, being number of votes needed to overcome any Republican filibuster that might block health care bill; it is also number of senators in Democratic caucus; number is also mirage, falsely raising Democrats' hopes that they have muscle to push bill without making concessions to centrists of both parties (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the Senate facing a potential deadline next week for voting on its health care legislation, interest groups have unveiled a raft of television commercials -- most of them arguing against the bill. A group called the 60 Plus Association, which bills itself as a conservative alternative to AARP, is spending $1.7 million to run commercials for eight days starting Monday.
docs.abstract: Interest groups run television commercials, most arguing against health care bill; advertisements are running on cable and broadcast television in four states; version in Nebraska and Virginia thanks Democratic senators for overhaul; in Alaska and North Dakota, ad criticizes Democratic senators who voted against it (M)
docs.snippet: With the Senate facing a potential deadline next week for voting on its health care legislation, interest groups have unveiled a raft of television commercials -- most of them arguing against the bill.     A group called the 60 Plus Association,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Pushing back against Republican assertions that President Obama's proposed health care overhaul would drive up medical costs, the White House said Monday that the pending Senate bill would ultimately slow the growth of health care spending by one percentage point a year. ''There's a lot of talk these days about fiscal responsibility,'' Christina D. Romer, the chairwoman of Mr. Obama's Council of Economic Advisers, said in a conference call with reporters. ''I want to tell you that what's going on on the floor of the Senate right now is probably the most important thing we can do for the long-run fiscal health of this country.''
docs.abstract: White House asserts pending health care overhaul in Senate would ultimately slow growth of health care spending by one percentage point per year; Christina D Romer, chairwoman of Pres Obama's Council of Economic Advisers, says spending would go up in short term as more uninsured people get coverage (S)
